stream_context.summary: Kaze focuses on Course 11—currently dubbed “Bowser’s Tower/Oily Boily Bay.”  Work centers on modeling the tower exterior, placing star objectives, overhauling UI (health & breath meters), and refining camera controls.  He also showcases broad re-works of earlier courses and tests N64 performance.
level: Course 11 (Bowser’s Tower / tentative name “Oily Boily Bay”)
Earlier courses (1,2,8) briefly shown for re-work demos

development_findings.summary: Course 11 layout clarified: three main stars (knock Bowser head; tower strike area where an enemy eats Mario; and a worker/star on the roof) plus retro owl-block gag.
development_findings.quote: “Star 3 is going to be here.  Guy eats you—one of the cleaning crew—and spits you out in a separate area.”

development_findings.summary: Level’s tentative name brainstormed; ‘Oily Boily Bay’ preferred for its rhyme/alliteration but remains un-finalized.
development_findings.quote: “Nothing comes close to being as fun to say as Oily Boily Bay—I think I surrender.”

development_findings.summary: Camera overhaul implemented: C-Left/Right snap-rotate, D-pad hold for slow rotation, R centers, reducing perceived input lag.
development_findings.quote: “Holding to rotate is gone… people were complaining there was too much input lag.”

development_findings.summary: Health-meter and breath-meter redesigned (now 32×32). Added smooth scale-in animation and darker color progression; uses dual-texture alpha threshold trick.
development_findings.quote: “You like that—how it scaled in, huh?  That was so easy… looks so good now.”

development_findings.summary: Breath meter duration shortened relative to vanilla to gate free-roaming on long Koopa-shell rides.
development_findings.quote: “I don’t want the player to just feel free to roam everywhere until they’re on a Koopa shell.”

development_findings.summary: Multiple early-game courses completely re-worked since demo; Course 2 retro section replaced with wider Mario 3 slide area for camera and frame-rate gains.
development_findings.quote: “Basically everything in this level has been completely reworked from the demo.  The framerate is higher.”

development_findings.summary: Considering new RSP microcode that disables near-clipping to fix camera pop issues.
Performance test on real N64 shows Course 11 still within budget but UV/fog issues and draw-order need optimisation.
development_findings.quote: “This stage already runs kind of poorly… it's all RDP—no optimisation yet.”

development_findings.summary: Future feature ideas: collectible Toad musicians (3 across overworld) that unlock a special overworld song; potential two-week sprint to add split-screen multiplayer during upcoming vacation.
development_findings.quote: “I get a two-week break… I was thinking of just doing a bunch of large streams—stairway I'm making multiplayer in here.”

context_findings.summary: Kaze works full-time as a professional game programmer; ROM hacking is unpaid passion so time is scarce.
context_findings.quote: “ROM making is not that lucrative, so I had to get a job… that is keeping me very busy.”

context_findings.summary: Prefers learning assembly before C; values deep technical understanding.
context_findings.quote: “Learning C before you’ve learned assembly is like explaining color to a blind person.”

context_findings.summary: Philosophy on tone: wants the hack to be a legitimate game, not a meme, hence rejects Twitch-style jokes in UI.
context_findings.quote: “This is a game, not a meme… I might be stuck-up, but that’s what I want in my life.”

context_findings.summary: Admits to 70-hour weeks and minor workout injury, yet comfortable with heavy workloads.
context_findings.quote: “I don’t mind working 70-hour weeks—I’m kinda just a little different.”

context_findings.summary: Personal moment: he and Zeina rescued an injured baby bird, reflecting caring side.

biobak.summary: Delivered new health-meter sprite set; iterated with Kaze to balance brightness so blue→green doesn’t brighten overall.
biobak.quote: “Me and Biobak went through a lot of back and forth to get these colors exactly right.”

biobak.summary: Modeled Buzzy Beetle and preliminary Bowser logo for tower façade; provided textures respecting N64 16-color limits.

zeina.summary: Appears on-stream, offers aesthetic feedback (flags, decorations) and discusses real-life scheduling (meal-prep during long dev streams).

key_stories.title: UI Revamp Breakthrough
key_stories.summary: Kaze wanted cleaner, less-obtrusive UI suited to widescreen and N64 limits.  Existing 64×64 Mario-head meter looked dated.
key_stories.challenge: Shrink meters without losing clarity and avoid unwanted brightness jump between colors.
key_stories.process: Biobak produced new sprites; Kaze rewrote rendering, used alpha-threshold dual-texture trick, added scale-in animation, tested on hardware.
key_stories.outcome: Meters are smaller, smoother, and pop-in elegantly; pause-menu issues fixed; design considered final.
key_stories.key_quote: You like that—how it scaled in, huh?  That was so easy… looks so good now.

key_stories.title: Retro Section Re-do
key_stories.summary: Original Mario 3 underground homage (demo version) caused camera jams and low FPS.
key_stories.challenge: Tight walls squeezed the camera and performance tanked.
key_stories.process: Widened corridors, added slide segments that mirror Mario 3’s physics, rebuilt visuals.
key_stories.outcome: Higher framerate, smoother camera, level now ‘completely different’ from demo.
key_stories.key_quote: The walls are wider so the camera doesn’t get squished—and I think the slides are really cool because that’s actually how the level worked in Mario Bros 3.
